Could see this being a bit of a trainwreck fresh, as even after 2+ months, its still VERY assertive and has a bit more pine and sourdough than I want.

Canned on June 9, 2016. Light golden. Puffy collar of nonuniform foam. Decent aroma of lemon, orange pith, resin, spruce, and a hint of pepper and herbs. Soft, but foamy and loose, carbonation. Hops are immediately overshadowed by a forceful surge of stinging alcohol and viscid residual sugars. Hoppiness steers toward nuance-pummeling resin and orange pith, with minimal floral and lemon notes poking through. Negligible pepper and herbaceous notes are mostly absorbed by the ongoing alcoholic glow, although do help to sharpen the mouthfeel. Malt is fairly refined and fluffy and helps negate the alcohol. Body lacks firmness, and theres very little dryness or minerals to cleanse the palate and offset the persistent resin and citrus. The finish is predominated by orange pith, yet contains salvaging haylike malt and a coarse herbal twinge which gives the impression of clean attenuation. While this lacks some of the nuance I look for the in the style, its better than expected from this average brewery. Too bad that its citrusy and resinous. A decoction would help give this some personality, and more lagering time coupled with a boost in minerals to firm up the mouthfeel would be welcome. Dry-hopping a lager is an unnecessary gimmick (especially with high-alpha PNW hops), but so it goes. No flaws or anything, just could use some fine-tuning. Serviceable.

text: 12 ounce can into lager glass, canned on 6/9/2016. Pours lightly hazy/cloudy pale straw/yellow color with a 1 finger dense white head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head. Aromas of grapefruit, tangerine, peach, lemon zest, orange peel, pine, cracker, biscuit dough, herbal, and floral/grassy earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of citrus/pine hops and moderate bready malt notes; with good strength. Taste of grapefruit, tangerine, peach, lemon zest, orange peel, pine, cracker, biscuit dough, herbal, and floral/grassy earthiness. Light-medium pine/herbal/spicy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, tangerine, peach, lemon/orange peel, pine, cracker, biscuit, and herbal/floral/grassy hop earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/pine hops and moderate bready malt flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance, and zero astringent hop flavors after the finish. Moderate dryness from bitterness as well. Very clean on lager flavors with zero yeast ester notes present. Medium carbonation and light-medium body; with a very smooth, moderately crisp, and creamy/grainy/sticky balanced mouthfeel that is great. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 6.3%. Overall this is an excellent hoppy pale lager. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/pine hops and moderate bready malt flavors; very smooth, crisp, clean, and refreshing to drink. A very enjoyable offering.

Taste is a nice pils bitter, citrus, grain malt.
This is a really nice one.

yellow. head. clear. Aroma is a mild sulfer, sweet grain,little pine,. Same in taste with some citrus. Something about this in taste and aroma that I really like. Its abv probably helps this lager. Peppery citrus.
I liked it a lot especially for a lager. The way it looked in the glass made me just want to pound it.
Taste and bitterness in an American lager! Knew immediately that this wasnt Bud---unless it was a bad batch of Bud that accidentally had some hops! 6.3% ABV was a bit higher than I expected.

Pour from a 12oz can. Clear golden brew with generous and persistent white head. Aroma of grass, tart fruit and a little spice. Taste is mild malt up front with an pleasantly complext bouquet of hops building towards the middle of the swallow - grass, tart fruit, a little earth, a little spice, hints of resin - ends with a moderately bitter and clean finish. Well hopped lager that retains the light and refreshing nature of the style. Nicely done.

From the can. Glad they canned this one. It will come in handy this summer. Nice clean crisp taste. Light like most othe popular lagers but has a nice little hop bitterness that sets this one apart. Another good job by Bells.

Pours a clear pale gold color with a frothy two finger white foam head that slowly settles into a lasting cap/ring. Very nice retention with streaks of soapy lacing left behind. Visible carbonation bubbling up. 

Grassy floral hop aroma with ale malt and a slight adjunct presence. Some grass, straw and light fruit with slightly earthy, grassy, saaz like hops. Theres also some pilsner malts apple and pear. Decent but nothing special about the nose. 

Medium bodied wih a crisp hop bite that lingers over the pale malt and sweet fruit notes into a dry finish. Bitter and dry with grass, straw and subtle pine needle followed by bread, biscuit, apple and pear. Theres also a weird adjunct like metallic graininess that I cant put my finger on which lingers after the finish. Crisp and refreshing with nice dryness but a weird and unpleasant aftertaste.
Draft. Pours a golden color. Aroma and taste are grassy, fruity, and some bitterness.

Draft at Khyber Pass. Clear yellow straw pour with a thin top of foam. Lasting ring. Very unusual powdery citrus flavors. Dried lemon peels dusted with honey corn starch. Tangerine pips. Snowflake bread rolls. Hints of dried pinecones. Vanilla ice cream. Lemon verbena. Plantains. Notes of sand tarts, oyster shells, buttered croissants, dream whip and toasted coconut. Standard base. Not huge or grand, but the flavors are just ... bizarre. And surprising. Which makes it quite noteworthy!

Pours a pale gold with a thin white head and a little bit of lacing. Aroma is pine hops, citrus, and sweet resin. Flavor is sweet citrus and pine. Has a smooth body. This is very impressive. Delicious.
A pretty dang good hoppy lager. Its a lot like Prima Pils, Id say, but a bit heavier.

I found this on the menu and tried it on a whim, knowing Bells Brewery puts out good products. What a nice surprise! It doesnt look like much, in truth, and the appearance is the weakest part of this beer, as its not much darker than your typical BMC type beer. But its got a nice crisp nose, moderately hopped, floral bite to the flavor. A very nice beer.
Tap...nice golden Lager color with a fragrant hop nose. Taste is of earthy, grassy grain and floral hops. Very easy drinking and delish.

text:
APPEARANCE ? straw color. Light head, gone in a flash.
NOSE ? clearly hop scent, but I don?t live it. Citra?
FLAVOR ? same taste as nose. Not so good, ma.

7/16/2015: Draught at Arnolds in Cincinnati, Ohio... Pale, cloudy gold color with a white head; this lager seems to be hopped up with citra... its grassy and tangy with some mellon and lychee flavors. Average body and mouthfeel. Seems to drink larger than 6.5%. Okay overall, but a pint was more than enough for me.

Pale lemony hue, perfect clarity. Small, silky head of white. Aroma is earthy, with soil and a splash of orange balanced by grass and grain husks. Flavor is clean and crisp, with hops adding a citrusy snap to the otherwise featureless brew. Maybe a little herbal mint in there too. Very dry.

Pint on tap at Yard House in Kansas City, MO. Aroma has some mango and passionfruit. Some bubble gum hints are also there. This smells like it may be hopped with El Dorado. Transparent yellow body with a medium, fizzy white head. Starts really fruity with raspberry flavors. Some herbal bitter hops to finish. My guess is that this place had a raspberry beer on before this and didnt clean the lines, which is why I get an overwhelming raspberry flavor to this. Larry Bell should be smarter than to sell his beer to a chain like Yard House.
On draft. Golden color with one finger head. Citrus, pepper and straw aroma. Taste is more straw, grass with slight citrus. Not bad.
Draft at Beer Run. Clear straw yellow with off-white head. Aromas of herbs and spice. Tastes of herbs, spice, light citrus. Light body with a dry finish.
Draft at Beer Run. Clear very pale yellow color, fluffy white head. Aroma of lightly peppery straw. Taste is clean and crisp hay and straw. Very nice.
Aromatic robust lager with an IPA type punch. This beer is very drinkable in a light clean fashion vs. The heavier weight that an IPA is sure to provide. Great taste.

Very light and clean pour with one finger of white head. Nice aroma, resinous and funky/dank with hops. Citrus and floral notes. Nice and lean/dry in the mouth. Touch of a grainy balance with a very clean and bright hoppy finish.

Draft sample @ Brewvival. Gold pour with a modest white head. Very hoppy, fresh. Some pine needle and a face full of grass clippings. Similar flavor. Countryside grass. A bit of lemon sherbet. Light malt backbone. Light body, active carbonation. Nice.
draft at Blue Monk, Buffalo NY. Golden colored medium pour. Crisp & easy drinking lager. grassy, light corn, solid bitterness. Nice lager
On tap at Bells. Poured light golden yellow with white head. Aroma of corn and light orange. Light carb med bod. Light resin taste bitter.

On tap at the Eccentric Café. The pour is a nice clearish golden color with minimal head and a spotty lace. The aroma is pretty good. There is a nice hoppiness and a gorgeous piney resin that really makes this stand out like an IPA rather than a pilsner. The flavor is just as good. The hoppiness and the resin are very profound with a light fruitiness and this is great. Very smooth and lightly bitter. The mouth feel is light, but decently carbonated. The aftertaste is nice and crisp with a lingering bitterness

Draft pour. See-through yellow. Aroma is lemon grass, biscuit malts, and lager yeast. A real nice amalgam of pale ale and lager notes. Taste is crisp citrus notes, bready malts, and a general earthiness. Finishes just a little bitter.
Draft - pours a medium gold , fluffy white head . Big floral and pine aromas . Moderate bitterness . Very good .

on tap @ Arnolds / Cincinnati OH --- Clear light amber with a slow to drop white head, splotches of lace. Taste is simple light malt with an immediate overbalance of citrus hops early in the palate. The hops, though dominant, arent very strong (since the malt is light to begin with, they dont need to be). The total effect for me is of a watered down IPA. Drinkable, especially in hot weather, but not at all memorable.

Sampled at the W&C Beer Fest 2014. It poured a blonde color with a white head. The aroma was of citrus, some floral hops, bread and yeast. The taste was of citrus hops, bread and yeast with a light palate and a crisp bitter finish. Very nice.

Aroma: pine, rose petal, and grapefruit on nose. Taste: bitter grapefruit and pine, bitter finish, some sweet caramel up front. Palate: Silky mouth feel. Appearance: Cloudy yellow body and creamy ivory head. 

Unique and almost game-changing, this beer will have you reevaluate what a lager can be.

6oz pour at Smoke and Barrel. Pours a clear gold with some lacing white head. Nose is a mix of lemony hops, yeast, honey, corn. Flavor is solid, lightly sweet, lightly herbal, mild soap, mild honey, a little yeast. Clean finish. Fine.
Pours light, clear amber with thin head. Aroma of strong pine hops, light citrus. Taste is light, bitter, pine, very light citrus. A little one dimensional

I had this at Global Brew. Pours clear gold with a white head. Taste hoppy, grassy. I thought this was good. I could drink this again.

Hmmm. Seems lost to me. Not something but is something. Oh no 29 characters to go + 1.

Draft at Jerrys. Brilliant orange-gold with good, foamy, white head, excellent fine lacing / Musty, lightly skunky nose of cream, citrus, candied sugar / Medium body, a hint thin, very hoppy but smooth, somewhat fat but lovely balance / Flavor of orange peel, hint of grapefruit, pine, spun sugar, biscuit / Drinks like a pale ale. Quite nice. For an imperial lager, probably rates higher than my score.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2014 Had on tap at Ashleys, pours a clear gold with small head. Aroma is hoppy  up front, grassy, with malt in the back. Flavor is snappy hops, medium mouth feel, lingering hops. Really big lingering hop bitterness. Bitterest lager Ive ever had.

Rated on 7-22-2010 at Ratebeer Summer Gathering in Grand Rapids, MI at Hopcat. This draft beer pours a small white head with a long retention, transparent body, no visible carbonation, and one ring of lacing. The aroma is malt, yeast, pine, crisp hops. The taste is malt, crisp, pine hops, and has a short dry finish. The palate is tingly and this beer is medium bodied. The flavors just did not come together very well and it left me not wanting this beer again. It is not a bad beer, it just did not suit my palate. To each his/her own.
Aroma of earthy hops and malts... The taste is fantastic with malt upfront and a hop finish. Nice

The aroma is earth, flowers, spicy. The appearance is clear god/orange, white head. The caramel, citrus hops, floral, nice. The finish is citrus, pine, lingering caramel sweetness. Medium in body. Very nice.
Pours light like a bud with big white head. Aroma of grass, light fruit, and wheat. Taste is bitter and crisp hops. Very dry finish.
On tap at Proof. Not much of a note: grass, herbal, bread, pine, wheat. Rating: 3.4. Ok, but I guess I wasnt a huge fan - dont honestly remember this one too well.

Draft at Proof. Clear golden pour with a bubbly white head. Very hoppy aroma, piney, spicy with touches a sweet pale malt. Flavor is similar with a clean lager finish. Not really a fan of this IPL thing that going on, but this one was pretty good.
Pours a clear golden yellow on tap with fluffy white head and good lace. Aroma of spicy hops, lager yeast, and slight grain. Taste follows, zesty yet clean. Pretty solid, no hint of the booze.
Draft pours light golden. Nose citrus hop, wheat, and an odd vegetal smell resembling celery. Taste citrus bite, bitter finish. Not much flavor in between.
UPDATED: JUN 25, 2016 On tap at the Michigan Summer Beer Fest. A fantastic lager. Has to be my favorite of the style. Still has that hoppiness though. Would love to get some of this.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2016 Tap: Straw-yellow body, bright and sunny with a hazy core and a stark white, chunky & cloudy foam that lasts much longer than expected; nice webbing left behind. Aroma is great; herbal hops, grapefruit, tangerine, heavy grass, pines, leaves, some faint mango and even papaya (generic tropical fruit). Lightly sweet pale malts, biscuits, crackers, and a fresh, clean note from the crispy yeast on the back-end. The taste is just as great... Pines, leaves, citrus fruits, tropical fruits, aggressive & herbal hops, all dancing on top of a light but sturdy pale malt backbone. Faint biscuits and bread with a chunky and crispy yeast-filled finish that shines once the hops fade in the aftertaste. One of the best "hopped up lagers" Ive had, mainly because you can still identify it as such. Goddamn, bring this stuff to six packs, Bells.

Had on-tap at Bells Eccentric Cafe

...Outstanding beer. I see the picture on here shows it in a bottle... what the hell? Is it rare in bottles? Id buy this a shit constantly if I had six-packs. Brewery only, maybe? Who knows. I sure as hell dont. This is a golden lager (imagine that) with solid lacing. Not too shabby. The smell/taste is what really gets me with this one. I think of it as Two Hearted with less bitterness... and maybe somehow someway even bigger floral/Fruity Pebble aromas. Holy damn is it nice. The taste is a bit more mild, but that only makes this even more easy to drink, and I dont have a problem with that.

Quinannan Falls Lager is most definitely "exceptional". People need to try this.

Pours a bright yellow with a small white fizzy head. Looks a lot like most lagers.

Smells of grassy/piney hops with a little cracker.

Tastes is unique. Definitely has a little graham cracker like crispness, but also loads of grassy hops with a little pineyness as well. 

Mouthfeel is a little heavy for a lager with good high carbonation level.

Always glad to try to a new style and I think Bells hit their mark here, but I wasnt the biggest fan. The hops were a bit too bitter with not enough malt support and the alcohol was a bit too present for its ABV. Solid brew and definitely recommended for something unique, but not my favorite.
On tap September 28, 2013 at ABR. Clear yellow pour with some head. Aroma and taste of grain and hops. A let down after the Black Note.

750 ml bottle shared by brew3crew in 2011 (notes). Pours a clear golden color with a medium sized white head. The aroma and flavor have a big grassy component, noble hops, citrus, apple, bready malt, light pine with good bitterness to the finish. For a style that I dont particularly like, this was a well brewed beer.
Tap. Golden with small head. Full flavored lager with nice hoppy bite. Very dry. Refreshing.

Pittsburgh Beerfest 2013. I was so glad to taste this! A delicious india pale, hoppy crisp piney bitter, up front with a grainy lager back bone. Similar to Great Lakes Silver and Gold IPL, only with a more potent flavor and a bubbly feel.

9oz on tap at Yard House Cincinnati. Clear pale yellow color. Thin white head. Good rows of lace. Bigger body. More crisp, kind of soft lighter carbonation. More dry in the finish. Nice grassy, light citrusy hop, and doughy, bready, peppery malt. Sort of piney. Hoppier than expected, a pretty satisfying aroma. Moderate bitter taste, light sweet, kind of zesty. Good, full-bodied imperial pils. Much better than expected.

On tap at The Federal, Durham. Not surprised to see this partly listed as a strong pils. Vigorously carbonated, deep gold pour. Noble hops initially in the nose, slowly revealing some nice fall fruit notes (crisp apple), pale malts, and hints of pepper. Modest pungent notes complement the bone dry finish, light fruit the bridge between them. Grassy as hell, almost like a cross between a really ripe saison and a pre-Prohibition lager. Really fine stuff.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2014 Sampled at the 2013 MBG Summer Festival. Very strong pine and floral aroma. Tastes like a forest, strong pine, spruce, grass and flowers. Barely notice the pilsner malt. Pretty good but Ive had better imperial pilsners.  Re-rate 3/14/14.  Full pour at The Oak this time.  Pours clear pale yellow with a big pillowy head that fades very slowly and leaves chunky, soapy lacing.  Aroma is pine needles, flowers, pilsner malt, spicy hops, and a very light fruitiness.  Taste is an awesome mix of stinging pine needles and crisp pilsner malt.  Finish has an awesome bitter sting to it with some spicy hops and sharp carbonation.  This is way better than I remember from the small festival sample I had.  Really love this stuff.  Definitely getting another pint.

Looks light-bodied, like a pilsener, but nothing else about this beer would make you think that it really is. It has a bright white head and an aroma thats strong of very floral hops... strong, and almost sticky, tree-like, gorgeous. I love it! It seems more like a turbo-hopped blonde than a lager. I simply love this. Its nose is infectious. It has a super-hopped flavor and a light body. Its awesome. I am very glad that they pulled this off. Its so freaking good. Wow!
Jesus Christ. If only Budweiser, Coors, etc. could taste this good.  They never will though.

I walked into a bar because I knew they had $2 draft beers and I was planning on getting pretty drunk, then I saw their menu and that they had this gem on it. So I got this instead of getting hammered, even if it wasnt cheap. Shitty mainstream beer has completely turned me off of pilsners or lagers but Ive been meaning to try a high rates one recently to see what a good pilsner or lager tastes like. Bells is by far my favorite brewery so what better one to try than this amazing rare beer. It came to me in a 10oz glass. It had a nice creamy thick head and a beautiful gold color. It kind of looks like pop though as its very effervescent and it also goes down like pop. I guess thats not too bad if thats what you like but Im not used to that in beers so it was a little weird. Not bad though. It smells really sweet, a little bitter and citrusy. It tastes very citrusy and sweet with a tiny amount of bitter. This is my absolute favorite pislner/lager Ive ever had in my entire life. If I ever see it again I will most likely get it without any hesitation. Bells never lets you down.

Bells is my favorite brewery. Larry Bell is a god. If you tell me that Larry Bell drank a beer in his dreams and then realized it. I will seek this beer out. I will travel to the ends of the earth and back for a chance to try this beer, and I do this because I know it will be worth it. And it is. Bells is one of those breweries that can do whatever they want however they want and it will always be amazing and this beer is no different. This is hands down the best lager I have ever drank. It Pours a fizzy murky lemonade color, with a thick white head and some lacing. Not much of a nose, a little hops and a lot of citrus and grass. The taste is hoppy too. A citrusy ipa flavor, with a pop-like lager body. If you ever come to a place where you can get a bells one off, do it. I?ll come right out and say it, I HATE lagers and I find this beer amazing. This is how all beers should be, delicious, alcoholic, and highly original. Leave it to Larry Bell.....

Draft at Mellow - strong hoppy aroma for a lager with a basic straw yellow pour, balanced and smooth taste with a mildly warming mouthfeel.

On draft @ the Brewpub.   Pours a medium golden with white head.  Aroma is hoppy, earthy.  Taste is like drinking a forest, very piney and crisp.  Top notch lager.

Tap. Pours golden just like a lager. Aroma of pine and citrus. Taste crisp like a lager but nice addition of hops. Finish is decent

----Hophaze out
South with clean flavors and a crisp refreshing feeling.  Aroma isnt really present but the taste is full flavored.  Easy drinker.

Tap at Sams!  What a nice surprise to randomly stop in here on a thursday night and find this rarity on tap!  Sams must be the #1 Bells account in the state because they have been getting lots of one-offs and other Bells kegs that you rarely see outside of the Kalamazoo area.   I was a little worried that this might be an old keg, but was willing to take the chance.  At sams you have to get a full pour, or nothing so I got almost a full pint of this magical lager.  And super magical it is.  I dont think I have ever had a better lager, and ofcourse this only had a few characteristics I would associate with lagers, but I am by no means an expert on the subject-actually quite the novice.  Pours a glowing yellow with light orange tints, a large, succinct and neat two finger white head with a steady sticky white lace throughout.  Nose is fantastic.  This is an strong pale lager/imperial pils.  Almost smells like a funky orval or a super dry Stillwater premium, super doughy, dry hops are in full effect, hardly any sweetness at all, just super fresh, light lemon and grassy tartness.   Flavor is equally amazing.  Super dry, lightly fruity, minerals, light leather and barnyard.  Again, very light sweetness, incredibly crisp and dry.  I had to drink this much quicker than I would have liked because of time constraints, but goddamn, it was amazing.  Clerk said they hoped to get another keg or maybe even some bottles as Bells has plans to brew this again.  I sure hope so.  Best Lager I have ever had, hands down.

On tap at eccentric cafe.  Golden clear yellow pour with a little white head.  Grassy aroma with some noble hop scent..  Bitter salty tingly taste at first, next comes grapefruit hop flavor mixed with hints of banana-like taste (yeast?), and burton salts.  Very nice lager taste.  Slightly numb tongue upon finish.  Above average carbonation with tingly mouthfeel.  Definitely one of the better lagers I have had.  Good hop presence with some sour European malt flavor.
Nice solid brew. Nice citrus and resin palate. Really easy drink. Lighter than most bells. Still solid
On draft at soup spoon. Creamy white head. Some citrus/malt/hay aromas. Crisp hay and citrus pith flavor without being overly bitter. Dry finish. It would be easy to put back a few of these.

Backlogged rating: Straw hued with fizzy lively head. The aroma has notes of noble hops, grassy and grainy with an earthy yeast tones, a hint of honey as well. The taste has a slight twangy fruit note, biscuity malts and a grassy/herbal hop note. Very faint pine and pepper hop notes as well. The mouth feel is crisp and refreshing. Very enjoyable lager that is overly boozy like many of the genre.

This draft brew from rbsg #10 poured a small sized head of foamy white colored bubbles that were and left behind a softly carbonated transparent yellow white colored body and a fair lacing. The mild aroma was malty and musty. The somewhat off-tasting crisp mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The crisp flavor contained notes of mild hops and mild lager. A decent one but not one that I would consider buying again.
Sort of IPA-ish strong lager. Pine and pineapple in the nose. Nice and crisp and bitter. Fine but prickly carbonation. Interesting and pleasantly drinkable.

On draft at Churchkey in D.C.

The beer is transparent, appearing a pale yellow color with a white cap. Nice aroma of citrus, hops, fruit, biscuits, subtle malt. Nice refreshing flavor. Hop forward with abundant citrus notes, exhibiting a lot of pale ale characteristics. Lingering bitter finish. Pretty dry. Overall, a really solid beer. It would be easy to have a few of these in a session.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 12-08-2011

30th December 2011ChrisOs Crimbo Tasting. Bottle 135/313. Clear pale gold beer. Tidy white head. Light semi dry palate. Lagerish pale malt. Nice hops - light orange and tangerine citrus with pine. Semi dry finish. One day all lagers will be made this way!
Bottle.  Its Bells...so you cant go wrong.  A nice citrus and hop flavor. A dry pine finish. Whats not to love?

Draft to pint (from notes).  Looks like a good lager; golden with white lacing.  Smells pretty good; hoppy.  Tastes nice!  Crisp and hoppy with a pleasant mouthfeel.  This is a great hopped-up lager thats a wonderful warm-weather brew (or any weather, for that matter).

Poured clear with a champagne color a nice small head adn great lacing. Aroma of pears and elderflower and a bit of floural hops. Tastes of a clean crisp nicely hopped pilsner with a bit of fruit essence. Palate is dry and crisp carbonation is perfect, overall it is a wonderful pilsner.

Bottle 189 of 313: &nbsp Straw in color, slight haze, large pillowy white head, nice lacing. &nbsp Hoppy straw like like aroma. &nbsp Smooth straw/hay like flavor, a little grassy, slightly dry, not too sweet, with a soft hop presense. &nbsp More bitterness comes out as it warms, but its still remains soft. &nbsp Lingering straw, hay, and grassiness. &nbsp Wished it were a bit more in body, heavier, and at 6.5% an IMperial Pils it seems a bit light. &nbsp However, its very well crafted and enjoyable. &nbsp Just not as big as I was hoping it would be. &nbsp A softer cleaner example of the style. &nbsp Thanks Kevin for the bottle!

Pre GTMW party at Maduro.  Filtered yellow-orange.  Straightforward beer-beer in a way.  Sort of a boho feel.Fruity tropical undercurrents bring to mind summit hops.  Very mellow and delicate, flowery.  Doughy, interesting tangy finish.  Different, well done, adds a delicate saison-ish feel to a lager.

bottle 67/313 from schiller on 11/25/11.

yellow with a frothy white head. 

aroma and flavors of peppery spice, mild grain, grass, peaches, mango, passion fruit and flowers.

medium bodied but crisp, spicy and very quaffable.
Light Golden clear.  Hoppy for a lager.  Surprising that it has lacing.  Thin white head.

On tap at a Bells taptackover.  This is no lawnmower lager.  Pours a light hazy yellow.  Taste is very malty.  Full bodied with the bready taste.  A hoppy finish in the form of a sweet piney taste.  Absolutely no hint of fruit.  And the alchol hits you after the pint!
Draft.  Crystal clear pale straw body, white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, herbal, some grass, light bread.  Taste is moderately sweet, grass, some herbal.  Light-medium body, light acidity, resin.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2012 Had this on draft.  Classic appearance of pilsner, translucent  light yellow color with a moderate white head.  Flavor was crisp and dry with what I felt to be the proper amount of bitterness for a pils.  I didnt know anything about the beer when I drank it and I was surprise to read the hops werent a noble hops.  Tasting a lot like I remember Prima Pils to taste,  I wish I could have sample them side by side. Excellent beer.

On tap at Oblivion. Nose is lemon and orange/citrus with some slight grain and malty notes. Quite hoppy and aromatic for a lager. Poured a nice golden yellow with a bubbly white head. Taste was a good amount of hop bringing bright lemony flavors and some tasty cereal and bran like notes. The grain and hops really work well together making a balanced brew that is very crisp and refreshing. A great drinker.

On tap @ Oblivion Taproom
Appearance -Typical yellow, frothy head, bubbly :-)
Aromas - Fruity, hops, dry
Taste - Citrus, hops, malts, smooth

This one surprised me, but Bells is known for its good beers. This lager was great, lots of fruity aromas and flavor - while being perfectly balanced in flavor. The hop flavor was a little high for a light beer - and was well on its way to an American Pale before the malts set in.

Draft at The Bridge, from notes. Pours a clear, pale gold color with a small, soft bone white head that laces the glass evenly. Aroma of pale malts, apple, grass, bread, crackers, and sugar. Flavor of sweet and pale malts, crackers, straw, grass, mild spices, and cereal. Light-bodied, with a malty, sweet mouthfeel and medium crisp carbonation. Surprisingly sweet. Not bad, but glad I didnt trade for it, especially when I heard how expensive bottles were.

Bottle 750ml. @ chriso [ chrisos festive get-together tasting ]. [ Bottle #135/313 ]. Clear medium orange yellow colour with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, fruity, moderate hoppy, citrus, shoe polish, orange - citrus, light grass - fresh grass. Flavour is moderate to light light heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration, well balanced. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20111230]

On tap; pour is slightly murky light golden with a modest, fine bubbled white head in this glass. The nose is light fruity notes, cereal, piney hops, and lager yeast. I have to say, this is a fantastic lager. Light bitterness, peach skins, cereal, lager notes, and American hops. Pine, and florals. Nice!

Courtesy of dcschiller at the Black Friday Tasting. It pours up clear gold with thin white head. The aroma is sweet with malts and some creamed corn as well as floral and spicy yeast notes. The taste is smooth spicy hop infused yeastiness followed by some floral and corn like notes. This is a smooth easy drinking brew with pleasing spicy hops where the floral hops and sugary malt sweetness dont get in the way for my taste.
750ml bottle, number 135/313, many thanks to Ken for bringing this one. Clear gold with excellent condition. Excellent hops throughout. Mouthfeel maybe a touch soft but otherwise top of the class.

At Chriso New Year 2011/12 tasting.  pale gold clear lasting white head.  Cats pee hop aroma.  Hoppy creamy some noble hop some tropical fruit.  Exquisite in mouth.  Good hops fresh as hell.  Just pretty much a drinkable as hell beer.  Mouthfeel is outstanding.  Beer of the day so far

on tap at redlight redlight.  Honey malts and citrus hops on the nose.  pour clear yellow gold with a thin white head.  Light and citrusy hop notes upfront with honey malts following then a kick of earthy bitterness.  The beer finishes with some bitter pine notes.  Man this is a quaffer!

Draught at Churchkey. Hazy yellow pour with a bubbly head. Nose holds HUGE mango, pineapple, guava, orange, and banana; just insanely tropical aroma. The flavor brings more straight grass bitterness, some dank herbal and crisp floral notes, and a touch of pink grapefruit. Incredibly crisp palate. If this were 10 bucks a six pack I could drink this stuff all summer long.

Draft. Pours blonde with a white head, nice retention/lacing. Aroma of citrus/floral hops, fresh bread, lager yeast. Taste is citrus hops, bread, yeast. Palate is light, soft, with a crisp bitter finish. What all lagers should aspire to be.
Clear yellow pour with a nice white head. Epic fruit floral notes with citrus and nectar lead to clean malt toastiness and rose water. Amazing.

Pours a clear golden straw color with a tall white head.  A touch of adjunct on the nose along with plenty of bread and biscuit malt.  Some floral hops and a bit of lager yeast.  The flavor is lightly sweet with some biscuit and bready malt.  Faint bitterness and floral hop flavors.

Draft at Rich Os. Clear, light gold body with a frothy, white head, slowly diminishing. Malty aroma with hints of spice and pepper. Notes of fresh, raw hops. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Flavorful beer for a premium lager  leafy hops with a clean, malt backbone. But then this is a 6.5% beer and above the guideline for a premium lager, strictly speaking. If Bells could make something this flavorful in a sessionable 4% beer ...

750mL bottle, #183 of 313, courtesy of wavers. Thanks, buddy! Pours a bright, medium-golden color with a thin, fine-bubbled head. Mineral and spicy hop character; a solid, zesty hoppiness. Crisp, spicy and mineral lager with a firm core bitterness; delicious stuff. Lasting mineral bitterness; nicely dry.
really great Lager. had at the ecentric cafe. hoppy dry hopped nose, some biscuity malts kinda bready but the higher hopping makes it really refreshing

Pours a clear lemon yellow with white head that quickly dissipates. Aroma is  grapefruit and nutty undertones. Earthy spruce notes. Flavor is a lot of grapefruit  with bitter spruce to offset the citrus bite from the grapefruit. Definitely notes of alcohol come across on the palate.  Body is light with active carbonation.

bottle courtesy of rayl101, thank you so much! this is indeed a special lager, very good stuff. pours very crisp and clear light gold with a small white spongey head. the aroma is very crisp with a good bit of piny notes and some slightwer floral as well. the flavor is just gret, with a great progression on the palate. the adjunsts and hops play very nicely off each other here. its got a moderately oily mouthfeel, but is still very light, crisp and refreshing. the hops surge up in the aftertaste beautifully here. really enjoyed this one.

On draught at Fourth Street Bar & Grill during the Bells Tap Takeover on 10/12/2011: Pours a clear golden color with a medium lasting white head. Short strings of lace. Aroma of biscuity malt and hops. Medium, crisp body with flavors of grainy malt, herbal hops and citrus. The finish is fruity at first and leaves a grassy hops aftertaste. Above average overall.
draft... bright dark clear straw, nice white head, nice looking beer... this is how all lagers should be, crisp, flavorful, with some great hops to add flavor, super easy to drink, worth trying

Pint at the Bells tap takeover at 4th Street Patio on 10/12/11. Clear yellow pour with a thin white head. Aroma of citrus, pine, grainy malt and lager yeast. Piney and grapefruity flavor with some maltiness before a bright and crisp hoppy finish. Pretty solid for a lighter-bodied lager.
sample at GABF on 10/1/11.  lt golden pour with a small white head.  nice bitter nose.  medium body loaded with hops - easy drinking with tons of flavor.  dry bitter finish with citrus notes.
Tap at Eccentric Cafe. Grapefruit hops, white grape, apple aroma. Yellow with a small white head and some decent lacing. Bready malt, apple, and bitter hops flavor. Medium body.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2016 Tap at Eccentric.  White grape, apple malt and citrus hops aroma.   Golden yellow color with small head.  Sweet white grape malt and moderate bitter citrus hops flavor.  Nice balance - a good drinker. / Can.   Dont really need to adjust - maintained the quality.

On tap at the Eccentric Cafe.  Pale golden color with a thin sticky white head.  Strong sweet citrus hop nose.  Some buscuit and cracker maltiness that is overpowered by a big pineapple and grapefriut hops.  Dry lager with just tons of hops.

(750ml bottle from Dak). Pours clear golden with white head. Active carbonation.  Aroma of resiny hops, perfume and grass.  Taste is sweet malts with light, but assertive hops.  Light bodied with an oily texture.  Bitter finish.  Nice beer!
14k gold pour. White head. Aroma of grassy hops, wheat thins, light caramel malt. Flavor is nice and crisp, hoppy, a phenomenal lager. Delicious.
On tap at Capones.  Perhaps the best lager I have ever had.  Light golden yellow color with that grassy aroma.  Perfect hop hit.  Just really tasty.

It pours clear light yellow with a pure white head on top. The aroma is light, almost nothing unfortunately but some light sweet notes. The body is smooth, not crisp as expected but full and pleasant. The flavors are light sweet notes with some hop presence not expected that make it delicious.
On tap at Capones. Golden pour with a small sized white head. Grains, citrus, fruity and some bread. Cookie dough comes out. Floral and grassy.

Clear golden with a lasting white head. Excellent lacing on the glass as it went down. Aroma was mostly hops. Crisp citrus fruits, floral, light malts. Medium, easy drinking body. Flavor was full of those crisp hops. Citrus and floral and nice crisp grass. The malts were about as clean as the best pilsener Ive had, which aided the hop bitterness. This one surprised and blew me away. I really got to enjoy the hops without having to wade through a bunch of caramel like in many IPAs (Not that Im complaining, I enjoy IPAs). I would build a bar around this beer. (Draft at Khyber Pass Pub, Philly)

Draught at Capones:  Fragrant aroma of hops, grass, light pine, dry-hopping, slight lager yeast, slight pils malt, slight bread, and more hops.  Poured gold in color with a small, loose, white head that lasted throughout.  Clear.  Slightly sparkling.  Good lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet and medium bitter.  Tastes of hops, pils malt, lager yeast, dry-hopping, light citrus, grass, slight pineapple, and some fruit.  Light to medium body.  Thin, dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Lightly sweet, light to medium bitter, hop, grass, lager yeast finish is dry.
Sampled at ABR in small glass.  Pours a clear gold.  A very nice beer, although not quite as flavorful as I would like.  But, as a lager it is very nice.

750mL Bottle. Thanks for sharing Sean! Clean, electric limey citrus aroma, strong and fresh. Combines with lagery crispness. Funny, the flavor hops arent as pronounced as the aroma hops. Not a ton of bitterness. Hop flavors and aromas a pleasingly citrus. Maybe not worth the big bones, but good.

750mL c&c #96 of 313 courtesy of rayl101. The pour is a brilliant cleat gold to lighter yellow with a larger, healthy white head. Rings of sticky lace. Nose is fresh pineapple, jackfruit, cantaloupe, ultra fresh biscuit and small butter, baked cherry, moderate alcohol presence. Really fresh and beautiful. Taste is really outstanding. A big interplay of fresh biscuit and mild butter with a massively crisp and quenching pilsener character. Very bitter, dry, doughy, grassy with sweet pineapple. Amazing malt profile. So clean even with some heavier butter biscuit in the mouthfeel. Hoppy, a bit boozy, grassy and sharp. So good. Ultra quenching palate. Better than most IPAs and richer than most Abbey Tripels. Pure hilarity. Kudos for making a pale lager that makes most craft beers run, hide, and cower.

Sampled @ GLBF 2011. Cloudy golden, creamy head. Grainy malt fight with spicy grassy hops for attention. Fairly dry, crispa and grainy with medum body. Growing floral bitterness. Very drinkable and pleasant.

tap at the eccentric cafe. clear, golden with minimal head. aroma of spicy simcoe hops, some citrus and pepper. flavor of spice, big lemon, pepper,  and some astringent bitterness...dry finish. clean, crisp, and refreshing

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2012 Had a glass of this at the end of the SW Mich brew tour about a month ago. I was pretty out of it by the time I ordered this and some Oracle (what the hell was I thinking?) Anyway, what I can recall, this was I guess the best lager ever. It had a pleasant sweetness, a slight tartness, and a wonderful hop presence. In other words, it actually had some character to it. Bells is selling 750s of these now for $17 a pop, which bums me out because Id rather see 6-packs or 4-packs even, and a lower price point. I would suggest just having some at the taproom if youre near Kalamazoo because it is damn tasty. Hopefully once the new brewing facility is up and running maybe they can crank out enough of this to put in 12 oz. bottles.

On tap at Maduro in Madison, pours a clear yellow with a decent white head and lacing, the aroma has an impressive amount of citrus and floral hops, the flavor is crisp and clean with a fruity finish and a touch of pine, very enjoyable brew.

Enjoyed at the brewerys tasting room.  A hoppy lager, very good for its style.  Dry hopped.  A nice lawn mower beer, and one that would replace others drunk in mowing days gone by.  Very good drinkability, and one that would transition many a macro drinker who does not realize he likes hops. Medium mouthfeel.
1st sip pure simcoe delicious w/ a nice sweet fruity and floral aroma.  Then the beer  falls off and gets muddied like a dirty wheat lager... aroma 9 taste 6 biz 3 pal 3

Pint at the Eccentric with the wifey. In truth, I ordered the Wild One, but kept taking surreptitious nips of this beautiful beer.  The pale straw color and moderate white head apparently had me hard-wired to expect a wan beer experience, but lo! this was anything but. Unexpectedly piney aroma with traces of cereal. Flavor brought forth more PNW hop character, accompanied by crisp graininess and minerality. Very dry finish. Q-falls is very likely Bells most underrated creation.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2011 On tap at the the Bells Eccentric Café in Kalamazoo, served in a tasting glass. Pours clear straw with a small white head. The head fades quickly to a thin remnant and leaves a small amount of white lace. The nose has satisfying lemony citrus notes along with pine and crystal malts. The flavour is dry throughout with straw and big hops with notes of fruit and citrus, pine and forest. The finish is clean with a lagerish quality. On the palate, it is light in body with a dry texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a decent crisp and hoppy lager that is more ale-like than I expected. 2011-08-14

On tap at Maduro - Pours clear yellow with a foamy white head. Light citrus hop nose, with apricot, light cracker malt--clean and crisp. Taste is light, fruity, but with a light, clean peach and citrus/grass hop finish. Has the same pale malt, with a real bitter, quenching component. Light-bodied and nicely carbonated. Beautiful.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2016 GTMW.  Brilliant, crystal-clear golden yellow.  Big hop aroma - pine, citrus.  Very present, smooth hop bitterness, with a brief glimpse of the pale malt, citrus lemon, and biscuit on the tail-end.  Residual crisp bitterness.  Very fresh and clean.  Low fruitiness and ultra-crispness only thing keeping this in the premium lager category and not the IPA category.  So easy to drink.  2016, new can.  Still has some nice grapefruit and pine character, just not the knockout I remember. -4

On draft at the GTMW. Pours pale amber with a finger thick white head. Aroma is lager malts, piney and earth. Flavor is much the same as the aroma. I could drink this beer all day. Light bodied and medium carbonation. Has a dry finish.

This beer was featured at the "12 Bells of Christmas" at Chatham Tap in Fishers, IN in early December.  First off, I have to start this off with wow. It pours a BMC like dark straw yellow with no head at all. It look no different than a Bud or Millter Lite. This deception leads to a greater finish. It smells great. It has this Gumballhead mixed with IPA aroma to it. It is very piny, floral, has hoppy bitterness to go with subtle sweetness. The flavor mirrors this. It has the flavor of Gumballhead mixed with an IPA to feature a perfect mix of the two. This is by far the best lager Ive ever had. It drinks very light and smooth. The content is very deceptive. It drinks so light and has exceptional flavor that this beer can creep up on you. It is excellent, absolutely phenomenal. Wow. Its disappointing that this may have been my only time to drink it. What a beer

On tap at Stub and Herbs Bells Fermented Eclipse Event. Reviewed from notes.

Pours a pale shade of yellow with a bit of haze. Several finger white head and a bit of lacing. Nose consists primarily of a really nice earthy pine scent with a bit of a floral aspect to it as well. Taste isnt quite as heavy on the pine, and adds in a bit of mild bready flavors. Mouthfeel is nice and dry with the spice. Although a bit heavy and unique in the flavor to be too drinkable, this was quite good.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-14-2010

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2011 On tap:  The aroma consists of light-moderate pine and grapefruit with a hint of honey.  It pours a bright transparent gold with a small white head that leaves behind spotty lacing.  The flavor starts with a very quick dose of light honey sweetness.  The finish is moderately hoppy with pine, grapefruit, and floral notes.   Overall its probably one of the hoppiest lagers Ive had in quite some time.  Very tastey and sessionable.  Light bodied with moderate carbonation.

I drank a ton of this stuff during the RBSG.  Pale straw coloured pour.  The nose is fresh and spicy.  Very dry, crackery malt base.  A nice minerality and a great combination of  noble and fruity American hops.  Lightly minerally.  Bright, clean, zesty and hoppy.  Lemon peel/lemon verbena.  Awesome stuff.

Draft at Eccentric Cafe.  Poured a light golden.  Medium white head.  Good lacing.  Hoppy aroma as it warmed up.  Bitter hoppiness similar to what Id expect in a pale ale.  Very crisp and clean finish.  Nothing that really jumps out at you on this one. Overall very solid.  Nice sessionable beer.

I dont remember writing this, but do remember trying to drink myself to death with beer. From my notes: "Super hoppy, super dry, beautifully clean lager yeast and crispy/snappy malts... This beer is a pimp!" And we all know pimpin aint easy. The scores for this beer are criminally low.

(Draught)  Pours a clear pale yellow body with a dense medium creamy off-white head.  Aroma of pineapple, citrus, mango, grass, pine, and florals.  Flavor of grass, mango, florals, earth, and honey with a dry, bitter finish.
tap @ HopCat for RBSG10 - sweet crackery malts, very pale yellow pour. Tasty with some nice spice and caramel.

On tap @ hopcat  Clear yellow with a white head. Light lager sweet malts clean nose. Thin smooth body. Pale malt flavors with a dry light bitter finish. Really dry finish touch of herbal hops. Crisp and super drinkable. Nice but didnt need that alcohol 7/4/8/3/15

Draft RBSG 2010 Clear yellow lager with a small, fizzy, white head. The aroma is very earthy, piney and cat pissy. Medium to full-bodied and pretty creamy with jazzy carbonation. The flavor mirrors the nose with lots of earthy, piney notes. Balance is good. Lengthy, moderately bitter finish. I could drink a boatload of this one.

On tap, clear yellow pour with thin white foam, bright lemon and yeast aroma,
flavors of honey, lemon, metallic , nice honey finish
On tap at HopCat while in town for RBSG.  Pours a light yellow gold with a thin white head.  Crisp grain aromas.  Grainy, light and crisp.  Smooth and tasty.  Quite well done.

Draft at Hopcat during RBSG. Pours a pale gold with a sticky white head. Hoppier nose than the IIPA I had at the same time, got lots of citrus and some light pine as well. On taste, a bit metallic at first with some clean honey and citrus coupled bitterness. Very easy drinking and refreshing. Nice fresh hop taste. Good stuff.

On tap at Hopcat.  Poured crystal-clear lighter golden with a sticky white head.  The aroma was fresh and bright with lemon zest over honeyed malts.. spicy fruit, earth, and pine joined in.. perfect balance with warm undertones.  The flavor had a sweet honey and lesser bready base with lively hop bitterness around (pine, lemon, and dusty, dry, peppery earth).. tangy bitter and lemony finish.  Crisp and refreshing on the palate, despite some warmth.. spicy, bitter, and engaging.  Excellent stuff!

On tap at The Green Well. Crystal clear, straw-colored, long-lasting white head leaving terrific lacing. Citrusy and spicy aroma. Light-bodied, highly carbonated with a long-lasting finish. The flavor is dry with a spicy and citrusy finish that keeps giving after each swallow. A terrific session beer. Out of the ordinary.

Pours a pale yellow with a small but tight head and some lace. The aroma is floral and citrusy with plenty of hop character and a very clean maltiness. The flavor is nicely spicy and very hoppy with some good snappy hop bitterness and intensely clean (if such a thing exists) there are light mineral notes as well. This is damned delicious and Id be happy to buy a good deal of it if it were on the shelves.

Bottle at Eccentric for RBSG. Pours a light golden with a small white head. Aroma is very clean and crisp, some cookie sweetness and and sharp earhty hoppiness that bites the nose nicely. Flavor is really nice and earthy while also providing a complex hop character that melds nicely with the classic pils taste while providing a nice American hop presence. Nice soft biscuit note with the fruit character. Medium body and a soft carbonation. Really nice beer

Draft at HopCat. Poured a clear amber color with an average frothy white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate earth hop and malt aroma. Medium bitter flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. My expectations where met.

Bells quinannan falls. Full pour at hopcat... Pours a golden pilner  
yellow brown with a thin soapy head... Aroma of fresh cut grass, fair  
bud, fresh with some grain... Nice dry hop flavor but gets grainy to  
some degree. Crisp carbonation. Nice aroma but flavor didnt hold up to it.  still very drinkable.
8/4/7/3/13

Draught at HopCat, RBSG 2010. Big fruity aroma with passion fruits. Nicely hopped with lots of citrus and ok bitterness. Nicely drinkable and flavorful during a night of huge beers. Would definitely like to try it again on a sunny afternoon.

Pours a deep gold with a fairly sturdy white head.  Aroma of crackers, bread, light hops.  Deep, malty dry flavor.  Somewhat fruity, doughy, some grain.  Tastes really excellent actually.  Like the kind of lager youd want to keep a whole shelf in your fridge devoted to.  Hard not to enjoy this one.  I liked it.

On tap at Hopcat during RBSG. Poured clear pale gold with a white head that dissipated to the edges. Aroma had a note of light fruits as well as some sweet grains and cereal. Flavor had a main cereal and sweet grain note with a bit of pine coming out in the finish and a hint of light fruit in the beginning.

Bottle @ Eccentric RBSG.  This was a quality brew, but Im not sure about Amarillo working with the lager yeast.  It was big and bright, somewhat grassy, but the fruitiness and orange of the Amarillo just seemed to muddy up the nice lager.  Easily the best lager Ive had from Bells (aside from Consecrator).  Medium sweetness, a bit toasty.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2011 7/25/10-Sample bottles at Eccentric. Awesome fruity hop nose. A bit grassy. Nice lager yeast character in the finish, slight sulfur. 8/4/8/3/16-3.9

11/25/11-Bottle at Black Friday tasting. Suprisingly tart, fresh hay aroma. Nicely grainy. Astringent finish. 7/4/8/4/14 3.7

On tap at Hopcat (Grand Rapids, MI). Hopcat 25 Bells tap event for RBSG kickoff! Pours a nice faintly hazed straw hue. A creamy white frothy head, mixed with a light floral aroma with light cereal grains. Enticing. Initial is a big hop bite for a lager, grapefruit and grass mix with grains and bread, a touch of crackers, lemon rind. Amarillo hops come into full play. A touch of gumball, grapefruit. Very tasty easy drinking lager with a telltale moderate hop bite magnified by the light body and easiness of the brew.

Served on draft at Hopcat in Grand Rapids, MI. Pours a clear golden color with a medium white head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of spicy, pepper hops with some stone fruit notes. The taste is peppery and spicy hops with some faint stone fruits. Medium bodied,
Tap at hopcat, pours clear gold white head, nose floral, grassy, fl grassy bitterness, floral and herbal, very simple malt base.
Sample at IN microbrewers fest. pours pale gold with pure white head. Piney, citrus, and notes of grass in the nose. light bitterness and finishes clean and dry. very nice lager, hopped like an APA.
Pours golden with white head, aroma is pine and a bit of spice.  Taste is like drinking a very light pine cone, with some slight malt finishing dry.  Not bad for a lager, hopped up for sure.

Not much aroma, slight hops. Not a whole ton of body. Flavour is equally thin but full of one dimensional hops. Could see this as an every day drinking beer due to the lack of a good selection of bitters and milds in these parts.

tap at 800 Degrees in Ft Wayne - Pours golden with a lingering one finger head.  The aroma is of hops with some lightly toasted malt.  It tastes moderately bitter with ample citrus accented hops.  The carbonation level is just right and with the medium body creates a very nice mouth feel.  Theres lingering bitterness and its a refreshing brew.  Very good.

Tap at Bells City TAP House event PBW10.  Pours a hazy golden orange with a medium off white head.  Aroma of caramel, bready malt and piney citrus notes.  Flavor of the piney hops coming through along with hard pretzels.
On tap.  Golden in color.  Bready aroma with some pinelike hops.  Taste is dominated by pine hopiness.  Really interesting and very tasty.  I wish this was bottled.

I am not sure about the "premium lager" categorization, as it is nothing like a pale lager or a pils. Nice golden color, and before I try it, I am hoping Bells has finally made a Bohemian Pilsner.  But this is something entirely different.  Aroma with some grass and hops.  Lots of hops in the flavor, citrus, as well as a bread/malt flavor.  Very drinkable, with an appropriately thin palate.

[Tap] Pours a clear gold with a soapy white head. Aroma is strong pine, some light lager yeast, some citrus fruits, and a little bit of metallic character. The flavor is very crisp and hoppy, like a combination of a pilsener and pale ale. Very pine forward with some orange and lemon notes, and that light metallic character lingering around. The finish is really nicely bitter and just lasts and lasts. Really happy to have tried this one.

[Draft @ City Tap House] Golden color with a small white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of citrus, toffee, light honey notes, and toasted malt.  Taste of citrus, grass, toasted malts, and light toffee and a semi-sweet finish.  Not bad at all.
Tap @ Eccentric Cafe. Clear golden colour, white head. Aroma is hoppy and flowery. Flavour is bitter hoppy, maybe some herbs? Soft malty.
Tap. clear yellow pour with a fluffy white head. Mild bread on the nose. Taste is yeast, maybe a touch of caramel. A lager? Best one Ive had.

WOW!! This ppoured a light yellow color with a white head. Aroma was very refreshing light citrus andpine hops and not much else. Flavor was very surprising nice amount of piney hops, some grapefruit too. Great hop flavor but not very bitter. Just so refreshing, this would be the PERFECT lawnmore beer.

Tap at Eccentric cafe.  Deep gold with minimal head.  Not a fan of hoppy beers, but dry hops appeal and this one did not disappoint.  Hop taste was there but subdued.  Good rich taste and very drinkable.

On tap at Crunchys, East Lansing. Clear straw body, thin to medium off-white head. A lager with the citrus, pine, and spruce of an APA or IPA, paired with light bready malts that lack sweetness or heft. A tad more "refreshing" than a hoppy ale, but I would typically choose the ale or a more subtle helles or dortmunder.

At Eccentric Cafe. Novel idea for a beer, clear golden color, small white frothy head. The beer has a decent hop aroma to it and the flavor follows, very clean and surprisingly hoppy. Best lager Ive had.
Tap at Bells. Pours a light gold with litltle head and convincing Cascade aromas.  Mmmm pine. Flavor is about like the offspring of an IPA and a lager and it is really good.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: On Tap 10/8/09 at the Eccentric Cafe. Description for the beer says "It came to Larry in a dream. Dry hopped Citrus Lager". Pours a clear golden color with damn near no head. Has some skunky b.o. funky smell to it. Flavor comes across as lots of Cascades, but I may be off on my hops ID.Crisp light finish...very Lager-esque. Much like Lager of the Lakes with a shitpile of hops thrown at it. Pretty good!
